meta.title: Congenital Heart Disease - Atrial Septal Defect

questions.text: An atrial septal defect (ASD) is a hole in the heart between the upper chambers (atria). The hole increases the amount of blood that flows through the lungs. The condition is present at birth (congenital heart defect). Small atrial septal defects might be found by chance and never cause concern. Which of the following is NOT true about the atrial septal defect?

options.label: A
options.text: One of the most common etiologies of right heart dilation

options.label: B
options.text: Many ASDs are not discovered until adult life

options.label: C
options.text: Reverse splitting of the second heart sound

options.label: D
options.text: ECG commonly displays an incomplete right bundle branch block

questions.correct_answer: C. Reverse splitting of the second heart sound
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Reverse splitting of the second heart sound The classic physical examination finding is a wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound, which is due to prolonged RV ejection and increased PA capacitance, which, in turn, delay pulmonary valve closure.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. One of the most common etiologies of right heart dilation is the presence of an atrial septal defect Option: B. Patients with large ASDs often present in childhood; however, many ASDs are not discovered until adult life Option: D. True.

Extraedge:

→ As there is very less pressure gradient across RA and LA→ This doesn't produce any murmur → The main murmur is due to excess blood coming to RA then to RV and pumped to P. Artery:- Flow murmur:- Ejection Systolic Murmur → Mainly heard in 'P' area There can also be a flow murmur due to excess blood through Tricuspid valve:- Mid diastolic Murmur:- heard in Tricuspid area → Extra blood coming to RV and more time to pass through pulmonary orifice :- P2 gets delayed

questions.text: There are 3 major types of ASDs or interatrial communications: ostium secundum, ostium primum, and sinus venosus defects. The ostium secundum is a true defect of the atrial septum and involves the region of the fossa ovalis. Small atrial septal defects usually spontaneously close. Primum ASD is most commonly associated with abnormal development of?
questions.correct_answer: A. Cleft in the Mitral valve
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Cleft in the Mitral valve A primum ASD is a deficiency of the AV canal portion of the atrial septum ; primum ASD is always associated with abnormal development of the AV valves, most commonly resulting in a cleft in the mitral valve.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B, C: AV valves NOT semilunar valves. Option: D: Less common.

questions.text: Which of the following investigation is diagnostic for ASD?

options.label: A
options.text: Auscultatory finding of wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Echocardiography Echocardiography is diagnostic. It directly demonstrates the defect and typically shows right ventricular dilatation, right ventricular hypertrophy and pulmonary artery dilatatio n. The precise size and location of the defect are best defined by TOE.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Other causes may lead to this finding. The most common cause of the paradoxical splitting of the second sound is the left bundle branch block. Obstruction to left ventricular outflow of sufficient severity to delay aortic valve closure may also cause paradoxical splitting. In the context of aortic stenosis, such an auscultatory finding implies severe obstruction . Other causes may lead to this finding. Option: C. The chest X-ray typically shows an enlargement of the heart and the pulmonary artery, as well as pulmonary plethora. Option: D. The ECG usually demonstrates incomplete RBBB because right ventricular depolarisation is delayed as a result of ventricular dilatation (with a ‘primum’ defect, there is also left axis deviation).

questions.text: For adults and children, atrial septal defect repair surgery involves closing the hole in the heart. This can be done in two ways: Catheter-based repair. A thin, flexible tube (catheter) is inserted into a blood vessel, usually in the groin, and guided to the heart using imaging techniques. In which of the following conditions, ASD should be surgically closed?

options.label: A
options.text: It should be closed in all cases

options.label: B
options.text: If pulmonary flow to systemic flow ratio is >1.5:1

questions.correct_answer: B. If pulmonary flow to systemic flow ratio is >1.5:1
questions.explanation:
Solution:

If pulmonary flow to systemic flow ratio is >1.5:1 Atrial septal defects in which pulmonary flow is increased 50% above systemic flow (i.e. a flow ratio of (1.5: 1) are often large enough to be clinically recognisable and should be closed surgically. The characteristic physical signs are the result of the volume overload of the RV: wide, fixed splitting of the second heart sound: wide because of delay in right ventricular ejection (increased stroke volume and RBBB), and fixed because the septal defect equalises left and right atrial pressures throughout the respiratory cycle a systolic flow murmur over the pulmonary valve. In children with a large shunt, there may be a diastolic flow murmur over the tricuspid valve. Unlike a mitral flow murmur, this is usually high-pitched.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Smaller defects may be managed conservatively and patients are monitored with Option: C, D. Severe pulmonary hypertension and shunt reversal are both contraindications to surgery.

questions.text: Aortic valve stenosis occurs when the heart's aortic valve narrows. The valve doesn't open fully, which reduces or blocks blood flow from the heart into the main artery to the body. The aortic valve area estimated by Doppler measurement is found to be 1.2 cm2. Which of the following is true about its severity?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Moderate AS Severe AS is defined by a valve area <1 cm2 Moderate AS is defined by a valve area of 1–1.5 cm2 Mild AS by a valve area of 1.5–2 cm2

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A: > 2 cm2. Option: B: 1.5–2 cm2. Option: D: < 1 cm2.

questions.text: Which of the following is preferable operation in congenital, non-calcific AS?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Percutaneous aortic balloon valvuloplasty Percutaneous aortic balloon valvuloplasty is preferable to operation in many children and young adults with congenital, non-calcific AS.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Its use has declined considerably because of the technical complexity of the procedure and the incidence of late postoperative aortic root dilation and autograft failure with AR. Option: C. TAVR for treatment of AS has been performed with increasing frequency in prohibitive- , high-, and intermediate surgical-risk adult patients worldwide using one of two available systems, a balloon expandable valve and a self-expanding valve.

questions.text: The three cardinal symptoms of angina, breathlessness and syncope are classically a feature of:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

AS Exertional dyspnea, angina pectoris, and syncope are the three cardinal symptoms of AS.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Syncope is less common. Effort-related dyspnoea is usually the dominant symptom . Option: B. Syncope is less common. Symptoms and signs depend on the underlying cause and how suddenly the regurgitation. Option: D. Syncope is less common. Until the onset of breathlessness, the only symptom may be an awareness of the heartbeat.
